Yes, there are eligibility requirements for each type of benefit. The specific requirements vary depending on the benefit, but in general, individuals must be residents of the UK, meet certain income thresholds, and be able to demonstrate a need for financial assistance. Some benefits are also dependent on age, disability status, or caring responsibilities. 

For example, to be eligible for Universal Credit, a person must be over 18 years old (or 16-17 and living independently), have a low income, and be actively seeking work. To receive Disability Living Allowance, the applicant must demonstrate that they have a physical or mental disability that makes it difficult for them to carry out a range of everyday activities.

There are also certain restrictions on the benefits that non-UK nationals can receive, depending on their immigration status. For example, some benefits are not available to individuals without leave to remain in the UK.

It's important to note that the eligibility requirements can be complex, and different benefits may have different qualifying criteria. Therefore, it's advisable to seek advice from a qualified advisor or to contact the Department for Work and Pensions for guidance.
